April 22, 1984: Fiction
THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.)
A lawyer is caught in a conspiracy to seize the Western world.
THE BUTTER BATTLE BOOK, by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $6.95.) A warning
about the nuclear arms race in words and pictures.
THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $17.95.) One man's experience in the bloody
wars of the Holy Land.
HERETICS OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam, $16.95.) The fifth volume of a
series about life on a faraway planet.
THE DANGER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $15.95.) A kidnapper at large in the
horse racing world.
LORD OF THE DANCE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Bernard Geis/Warner, $17.50.)
In seeking her long-lost cousin, a teen-ager probes the mysteries of life and death.
SMART WOMEN, by Judy Blume. (Putnam, $15.95.) Three divorcees, their love
affairs and their kids in trendy Boulder, Colo.
PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town
discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery.
ONE MORE SUNDAY, by John D. MacDonald. (Knopf, $15.95.) Behind the
scenes with a charismatic television preacher.
WHO KILLED THE ROBINS FAMILY?, created by Bill Adler and written by
Thomas Chastain. (Morrow, $9.95.) The publisher offers a $10,000 prize to the
reader who submits the best answer.
ALMOST PARADISE , by Susan Isaacs. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Three
generations of show-biz people play out their destinies on two continents.
POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of
history in fictional form.
UNTO THIS HOUR, by Tom Wicker. (Viking, $19.95.) Three days in August, 1862,
when a battle was fought at Manassas, Va.
THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian
monastery.
FLOODGATE, by Alistair MacLean. (Doubleday, $15.95.) Terrorists threaten to
flood the Netherlands unless Britain leaves Northern Ireland.
April 22, 1984
Non-Fiction
MAYOR, by Edward I. Koch with William Rauch. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) New
York's mayor's opinions about his job, his city and the world.
THE MARCH OF FOLLY, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $18.95.) The blunders
of government in four periods, from Troy to Vietnam.
ONE WRITER'S BEGINNINGS, by Eudora Welty. (Harvard University Press, $10.)
The novelist recalls her childhood in Mississippi.
MOTHERHOOD: The Second Oldest Profession, by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-
Hill, $12.95.) A humorous look at the biggest on-the-job training program ever.
TOUGH TIMES NEVER LAST, BUT TOUGH PEOPLE DO! by Robert H. Schuller.
(Thomas Nelson, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California preacher.
MAFIA PRINCESS, by Antoinette Giancana and Thomas C. Renner. (Morrow,
$15.95.) Growing up in the family of the mobster Sam Giancana.
LINES AND SHADOWS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Perigord/Morrow, $15.95.)
Adventures of the San Diego police force that stalks bandits along the Mexican
border.
ON WINGS OF EAGLES, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $17.95.) The rescue of two
Americans from an Iranian prison.
FURTHER UP THE ORGANIZATION, by Robert Townsend. (Knopf, $15.95.)
Business strategies for the 1980's.
IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr.
(Harper & Row, $19.95.) Lessons to be learned from well-run American
corporations.
THE DISCOVERERS, by Daniel J. Boorstin. (Random House, $25.) Man's search
to know himself and the world over the centuries
PEOPLE OF THE LIE, by M. Scott Peck. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) A
psychiatrist's prescription for ''healing human evil.''
TOUGH-MINDED FAITH FOR TENDERHEARTED PEOPLE, by Robert H.
Schuller. (Thomas Nelson, $14.95.) More inspiration from a California preacher.
THE BEST OF JAMES HERRIOT. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Selections from the
writings of the Yorkshire veterinarian.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $12.45.) Light verse
and drawings by the author.
